rev.diff:
Line 71: Line 71:
In {{by|1901}}, he became manager, general manager, and part owner of the new American League's [[Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia Athletics]].
In {{by|1901}}, he became manager, general manager, and part owner of the new American League's [[Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia Athletics]].
â   â
[[Image:Conniemacks.jpg|left|thumb|Connie Mack statue, overlooking [[Citizens Bank Park]], and skyline of the City of Philadelphia ]]
 
Mack managed the Athletics through the [[1950 Philadelphia Athletics season|1950]] season, for a record of 3,582-3,814 (.484) when he retired at age 87. His 50-year tenure as Athletics manager is the most ever for a coach or manager with the same team in North American professional sports, and will likely never be threatened. He won nine pennants and appeared in eight [[World Series]], winning five.

He won nine pennants and appeared in eight [[World Series]], winning five.
